title-group.article-title: Feasibility of acquiring occupational data from cancer patients’ medical records in Malaysian oncology centres

sec.title: Background
sec.p: In Malaysia, data on occupational cancer are severely lacking in medical records across the healthcare system. Incomplete or missing information on occupational background, stemming from non-mandatory reporting in routine patient history taking, has led to the underreporting of cases. This study aimed to evaluate the availability of occupational data in the medical records of cancer patients.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The study was conducted from May to September 2023 in two oncology centres in the Klang Valley. These centres have different record keeping systems, with one utilizing an electronic system and the other using a paper-based system. Medical records of cancer patients were screened for availability of occupational details. Data were then collected from 962 medical records of patients with documented history of working and 314 patients were interviewed regarding their occupational history to compare with the records. Descriptive analyses of frequency for available occupational details and chi-square tests were performed with statistical significance set at p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The centre with paper-based record keeping system had higher recorded occupational details at 88.5%. The availability of specific types of occupational details was mostly higher among electronic medical records. The highest information recorded in medical records was for occupational classification (81.1%) and lowest for occupational exposure (0.2%), which is one of the most crucial pieces of information in establishing occupational cancer diagnosis. When comparing between medical records and interviews, only 65.3% demonstrated similarity in capturing the work classification. Additionally, 23.6% of data were incomplete or missing, and thus could not be compared. Another 8.9% showed some discrepancy in the classification.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study underscores the need for improvement in collecting detailed occupational history from cancer patients. Identification of possible occupational exposure is a fundamental step in determining the possibility of work-related cancer.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12889-025-24284-w.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Cancer is a complex disease influenced by various risk factors and often involves a long latency period, making it difficult in ascertaining its root causes [1, 2]. However, most occupational or work-related cancer have identifiable causes, often linked to specific exposures, that are preventable through control or elimination of hazardous agents [2]. The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) has listed some of the carcinogens related to occupational cancer such as radiation, industrial chemicals and night shift [3]. Therefore, documenting relevant occupational history and workplace exposure data is an essential steps in understanding the potential link between occupation and cancer risk [4].

Cancer registries can serve as a valuable tool for supporting epidemiological studies on occupational cancer, provided they are effectively designed and maintained to capture relevant occupational information from patients’ medical records [5],. Furthermore, in a developed country, occupational cancer surveillance system was reported as a feasible method in identifying hazardous agents’ exposure among the workers at the local and national level [6].

In Malaysia, effort to establish a cancer registry began in 1993, initially involving a few states, and later expanded to all states by 2007 [7]. This effort has led to an increase in documented cancer cases, despite the reporting system being voluntary [8]. Comprehensive cancer registration in Malaysia was achieved through a combination of passive and active case-finding methods, utilizing multiple data sources [7]. Initially, the data were collected manually via hardcopy forms and entered into the CanReg5 computerised database [7]. A significant technological advancement took place in 2018 with the introduction of online cancer case reporting, further enhanced by the mandatory implementation of online cancer notifications in 2020 [8]. Consequently, reported cancer cases increased from 115,238 in the 2012–2016 period to 168,823 in 2017–2021, reflecting a significant improvement in cancer surveillance capabilities [8].

Despite this progress, several gaps persist in the current registry system globally including Malaysia. One of the most critical gaps is the lack of systematic collection of information related to occupation [9, 10]. Considering the long latent period for some occupational cancers, and the fact that it may be diagnosed even after discontinuation of employment, capturing the occupational history can aid in both retrospective assessment of disease causes and prospective preventive efforts [9, 11].

Moreover, identifying occupational cancer is important because affected individuals may potentially receive medical compensation, insurance coverage or social protection, and it enables targeted intervention to reduce similar occurrence in the future [11]. However, only a limited number of occupational cancer cases are being reported globally including in Malaysia [9]. Lack of information pertaining to occupational exposure has led to severe underreporting of work-related cancer. In 2021, the Department of Occupational Safety and Health Malaysia (DOSH) reported only one confirmed case of occupational cancer being notified [12]. While the Malaysia Social Security Organization (SOCSO) received six claims for occupational cancer [13].

Another underlying issue is the limited emphasis placed on occupational history in routine clinical documentation [5, 14]. A study in Turkey among medical faculty physicians concluded that missing or incomplete occupational data in the medical records were due to limited training or awareness among medical practitioners on the importance of occupational history taking [15]. The importance of capturing occupational data in Malaysia is further highlighted by the country’s economic structure. Malaysia has a diverse industrial landscape that includes manufacturing, agriculture, construction, mining and quarrying [16]. Therefore, understanding the occupational background of cancer patients can provide critical insights into exposure-disease relationship.

However, without reliable and accessible data, the efforts to link the occupational exposures to cancer will remain limited. Hence, assessing the feasibility of acquiring occupational data from cancer patients’ medical records is the first step before designing robust epidemiological studies that investigate exposure-disease relationships. This would guide in mapping future directions towards reducing the burden of occupational cancer in Malaysia and contribute to the improvement of the cancer registry system in Malaysia. Thus, this study aimed to determine the availability of occupational data from medical record of cancer patients in oncology centres in Klang Valley, Malaysia.

Among five oncology centres in Malaysia, Klang Valley was selected due to its high concentration of major oncology centres and the operational base of the study authors. A secondary aim of this study was to determine whether there were differences in the availability of occupational data between a centre that was still using paper-based records versus one that had transitioned to electronic medical record (EMR) systems. A digital hospital refers to a healthcare facility that aims to translate medical information into an electronic data system and utilizes information systems to store and retrieve them, with the intention of improving processes, decision making, and automation [17]. This study also assessed the discrepancies between occupational data recorded in the paper-based record system and those obtained through patient interviews at a single site. Identifying such differences may guide targeted strategies to improve occupational data captured across varying documentation platforms.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This observational study was conducted between May and September 2023 in two major oncology centres in Klang Valley, Malaysia. Both oncology centres received patients from the local area and nationwide as they serve as national referral centres, providing radiotherapy, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and palliative care services. These two centres applied different types of record keeping with one centre using digitalized system or EMR, while the other centre used non-digitalised, paper-based medical record.

The study was designed to assess the availability and completeness of occupational information documented in cancer patients’ medical records across both settings. The availability of occupational details is defined as any occupational information documented in the medical record. During the study period, a total of 1,976 data from medical records were screened for availability of occupational details.

In addition to medical record review, face-to-face interviews were conducted with patients at one site primarily due to study feasibility. The paper-based centre was chosen to compare patient-reported occupational history with the corresponding documentation in medical records. This approach enabled not only a comparison between manual and electronic systems, but also the reliability of recorded data through patient input (at one site).

sec.title: Data collection from medical record
sec.p: The inclusion criteria in obtaining occupational details were [1] Malaysian nationality [2], diagnosed with any cancer after year 2020, and [3] has history of a minimum one year of working at one place at a time either full-time or part-time. Patients diagnosed from 2020 onwards were selected because they were more likely to still be undergoing treatment and able to participate in interviews. This also ensured that the data reflected the most recent documentation practices at both facilities. Additionally, the inclusion of recently diagnosed patients, who were more likely to be currently employed or to have ceased employment only recently, helped minimize recall bias and enhanced the accuracy of the occupational data obtained. The exclusion criteria were duplicate medical records.

From the total 1,976 screened medical records in both centres, 962 patient’s data met the inclusion criteria and were included in further data collection and analysis. The extracted data included sociodemographic, and occupational details. The collected occupational details were: [1] occupation; referred to the designation or job title [2], job classification; referred to occupational information that can at least be categorized to major groups of Malaysia Standard Classification of Occupations (MASCO) [3], work sector; referred to any information that could be used to categorize employment by sector according to the Institute of Labour Market Information and Analysis (ILMIA) [4], workplace; referred to workplace or the place where patient worked [5], work duration; referred to the duration patient had stayed working in year/s [6], hazardous exposure; referred to any hazards that the respondent was exposed to at work [7], previous work; included any history of work in addition to current/last occupation. Occupational data that did not specify the nature of the job, such as job title, role or description that allows for appropriate classification were deemed incomplete. These occupational details were typically recorded by physicians from history taking and provided critical information for a comprehensive assessment of work-related exposure relevant to cancer diagnosis.

sec.title: Interviewed based questionnaire
sec.p: All 314 cancer patients from the oncology centre with paper-based record system were interviewed during their visit. These interviews were carried out only at the paper-based centre due to logistical considerations. They were conducted by trained interviewers with details of the study explained to the respondents and written informed consent obtained before the commencement of interview session. Specifically, current and past occupational details including occupation, classification, sector, workplace, duration of work, and hazardous exposure were recorded in the questionnaire.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using the IBM Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) software version 28.0 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA). Simple descriptive analysis of frequency (percentage) was used to analyse the sociodemographic and occupational details. Subsequently, clustered column was used to demonstrate the frequency distribution on the types of occupational details available in the medical record. Chi-square tests were performed to examine associations, with statistical significance set at p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Prior to data collection, a total of 1,976 data were screened from both centres. There were 1,057 data from electronic record and 919 from paper-based record. Availability of occupation data was slightly higher from paper-based records (n = 813, 88.5%) as compared to electronic record keeping centre (n = 897, 85.3%). From the total screened data, 962 (48.7%) data were included for this study (Fig. 1). Table 1 summarized the characteristics of respondents from both oncology centres. Respondents were predominantly female (54.9%), of Malay ethnicity (55.2%), ever married (86.6%), had no parent with history of cancer (58.0%) and has job classification as professionals (19.1%).Table 1

Occupational details recorded in the medical records were typically documented using brief, non-standardised phrases, often lacking sufficient context. Hence, the information was extracted based on the availability of data corresponding to the occupational categories outlined in Fig. 2. The majority of records documented were work classification (81.3%) or job title (62.9%) with limited information on duration of employment, potential hazardous exposure and previous work experience. Some of the data only contained general details such as the sector or place of work. Limited information such as retired, self-employed, government servant, working at private company and position at work were considered incomplete data as it does not provide any context of the occupation types, nature or exposure.Fig. 2
Types of occupation detail available in medical record (N = 962)

When comparing between the two record keeping methods, electronic record keeping showed a higher percentage of data availability on the occupation, work classification, work sector, and place of work with a significant difference in the findings compared to paper-based records (Table 2).Table 2

sec.title: Similarities in work classification captured in paper-based by medical records and survey findings
sec.p:
All 314 patients from the paper-based centre were interviewed during their oncology visit for comparison with their occupational details in the medical record (Fig. 3). For this study, only work classification was compared for similarity, as it was the most consistent type of data available to capture similarities or discrepancies compared to other type of data. The similarity was categorized subjectively based on the details provided, according to the MASCO, comprising 10 major groups (MASCO,2020). When compared with medical records, 205 (65.3%) revealed similar findings. A total of 28 data (8.9%) showed discrepancies in work classification between medical records and interviews. Meanwhile, another 74 cases (23.6%) could not be compared due to incomplete data in the medical records.Fig. 3
Comparison of work classification between medical record and patient’s interview

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Work related cancer is not easily recognized as it can appear years following initial exposure or after retirement. Identifying the link could be made more difficult among those with multiple occupations. Thus, a detailed occupational history, which includes previous work experiences and work exposures are important in identifying probable work-related cancers [2, 4]. This study found limited information on occupational details reported in the medical records from both oncology centres. The available data were also inadequate, mostly only limited to work classification (81.1%) with almost no information on exposure at the workplace (0.2%).

The early screening process showed that the centre with paper-based record keeping system, where occupational history was written manually, had a higher percentage (88.5%) for availability of occupational information compared to centre with EMR (85.3%). The EMR system used in the studied facility includes a designated free-text field for occupational information, although it did not enforce mandatory completion. As such, the recording of occupational information depends heavily on physician awareness and initiative. Additionally, limited access to computers and lack of point-of-care documentation have been shown to delay data entry in EMR leading to data inaccuracy [18]. This could also be influenced by the complexity and skills required to use the system efficiently and the lack of prompt for the entry of occupational information [19, 20]. Other studies have also reported dissatisfaction among clinicians with the completeness and correctness of data recorded in EMR [21, 22].Additionally, the system can be more time consuming to navigate compared to handwritten records, leading to reduced time for patient interactions [23, 24]. This limitation also reflects the broader institutional or higher-level decisions made during procurement of the systems to be used in the facility.

Despite the lower availability of occupational information in EMR from the screening data in this study, more information on specific type of occupation details were able to be categorized from this system. Higher availability of specific occupational details including job title, work classification, work sector, workplace and exposure were observed from EMR. This contrasted with the observation from one study that reported higher chance of data entry errors in the free-text field, potentially contributing to incomplete occupational information [20]. Given the circumstances, with mandatory requirements or system design to capture detailed occupational information including exposure history in the EMR, more complete and relevant data could be documented.

This study showed a higher availability of occupational data compared to a study in North Carolina which had about 40.3–42.2% data for type of occupation, and 43.5–42.2% for type of industry being reported from 2020 to 2021 [25]. Another study analysed occupational data in the Florida cancer registry among firefighters. They reported approximately 53% of occupational code were available to enable classification of workers into detailed occupations [26]. Meanwhile, data on the duration of work, hazardous exposure and previous work were severely lacking with less than 2% of records having this information. Of note, the lack of exposure data imposes a great challenge to physician to attribute the cancer causes to specific exposures or risks [27]. Based on a review done on the occupational cancer burden in Great Britain, the population attributable fraction of total cancer as a result of occupational exposure ranged between 2% and 8% [28]. Whereas, in Italy, 0.9% of cancer diagnosed and 1.6% of cancer mortality were attributable to occupational exposure to carcinogens [29]. This implies the importance of exposure data, as a substantial proportion of cancer diagnoses were due to occupational exposure.

When compared with patients’ interview in this study, only 65.3% showed similarity in work classification as documented in the medical records, whereas, 8.9% showed total discrepancy. The discrepancy was higher compared to a study in Norway which reported 5% inconsistent information between electronic and paper-based record [30]. The discrepancy could also be attributed by previous occupational histories that were not captured in either the record or by the interviewer. Additionally, using systematic and comprehensive checklists that encompasses key occupational information during history taking can help in preventing discrepancies and missing data. Studies have shown that systematic screening of occupational exposures can improve the identification of work-related cancers and support compensation efforts [31–33].

While history taking is a key component in reaching a diagnosis, occupational history is often neglected, leading to underdiagnoses of work-related cancers [14]. Occupational information is often perceived as neither useful nor urgent, and the assessment is viewed as complex [34]. The lack of knowledge and awareness among medical practitioner on the importance of occupational information and the details required to establish work-related diseases, could influence the quality of the data collected [35]. Specifically for exposure, the intensity and duration are important information needed to establish the work-relatedness of the cancer outcome [32]. Additionally, the lack of standardized definitions of exposure and diagnostic criteria for occupational diseases impedes the process of collecting this information [36]. A comprehensive occupational history is therefore important in establishing a link between occupation and disease, which subsequently can expedite work-related diagnosis, prompt treatment, and facilitates compensation process [14].

In this study, data on occupations are mostly available in medical records. However, the depths of information are scarce. Most information is limited to only the current or last job title, with little information on previous jobs, the work activity, exposure at workplace, intensity or duration of exposure that could provide information to possible causes of work-related cancer.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: To the authors’ knowledge, this study was the first to investigate the acquisition of occupational data from cancer patients’ medical records in Malaysia. This pioneering effort is crucial in assessing how well attending medical practitioners documented occupational histories. The study provided valuable baseline data on the availability of occupational history, highlighting gaps in collection of information. Understanding these gaps is essential for improving documentation on occupation during patient consultations. Comprehensive occupational details could establish a link between occupation and cancer, which is important for diagnosis, planning and implementation of preventive strategies, and compensation claims.

However, this was a descriptive feasibility study with a small sample size involving two centres in Malaysia. Furthermore, the patient interviews were conducted only at a single site, which was the paper-based oncology centre. Although the findings from the interview component may not be generalizable to other settings and may introduce potential bias, it provided valuable insight into the discrepancies between patient-reported occupational history and the information recorded in medical records, highlighting specific gaps in documentation practices. In addition to that, recall bias may have affected the accuracy of self-reported occupational information, particularly among patients with long work histories or complex employment backgrounds. Moreover, present study did not explore the underlying reasons for gaps in documentation of occupational data or discrepancies between patient interviews and medical records. Hence, additional studies are needed to investigate the reason behind incomplete or inconsistent occupational information in records. Specifically, research focusing on medical practitioners’ practices and factors contributing to these discrepancies would provide deeper insights into improving data collection methods.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A detailed occupational history with information on work description (what kind of work the patient actually did, not just the job title) and exposures (type of chemicals, length of exposure, use of personal protective equipment) are essential to assist in the diagnosis of occupational cancer. Although an acceptable percentage of occupational data was available in both EMR and paper-based systems in this study, the type of information recorded was inconsistent and very brief. Details on specific exposures were often missing, and most records contained only the job title and workplace. Manually entered paper-based systems sometimes offer better data availability. However, there were discrepancies in the data retrieved from medical records with data collected from patients’ interview in this study. This emphasizes the need for standardization in occupational history taking. Health professionals need to be trained to be more equipped with the skills for occupational history taking. This includes improving their knowledge and awareness of occupational cancers and the importance of occupational history taking. Additionally, improving data collection by implementing mandatory fields in electronic records and using a systematic checklist could enhance the accuracy of occupational record keeping, ultimately leading to better diagnosis and management of work-related cancers.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the Director General of Health Malaysia for the permission to publish this article and the Director of the Institute for Medical Research Malaysia for the support given. We also thank Department of Radiotherapy and Oncology, Hospital Kuala Lumpur and National Cancer Institute, Ministry of Health Malaysia for their cooperation and support during data collection.

notes.title: Authors’ contributions
notes.p: NM, RI, MAO and RS: Conceptualization, and methodology. NM, RI, NAKH, NMNNH, SR: Investigation, data collection and data curation. RSA and NLB: support in data collection. NM: Formal analysis. NM, NAKH, SR and RI: Analyzed the data and interpreted the results. NM, NAKH and SR: writing the original draft. NM, RI, NAKH, NMNNH, SR, NKRMY: Writing- review & editing. All authors: critically revised the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: The research was funded by the Ministry of Health Malaysia (NMRR ID-22-00745-72 C).

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The data from the current study are not publicly available due to privacy and third-party restrictions but are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

notes.title: Ethical approval and consent to participate
notes.p: This study was reviewed and approved by the Medical Research and Ethics Committee (MREC), Ministry of Health, Malaysia [No. 22-00745-72C(1)]. Approval was obtained from the director of the oncology centres prior to the commencement of the study. The participants provided their written informed consent before participating in the study. All participants were anonymous without any identifier appearing in any report. This study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
